title: Track and Field
description: How well do you know athletics, from sprinting to throwing events?

questions.question: What distance is a standard outdoor running track?
questions.explanation: A standard outdoor running track is 400 meters (approximately one-quarter mile) around one lap. The inside lane is exactly 400 meters, with outer lanes being progressively longer.

questions.question: What are the four throwing events in Olympic track and field?
options: Shot put, discus, javelin, ball throw
Shot put, discus, javelin, stone throw
Shot put, discus, spear, hammer throw
Shot put, discus, javelin, hammer throw
questions.explanation: The four Olympic throwing events are shot put, discus, javelin, and hammer throw. Each event requires different techniques and levels of strength and coordination.

questions.question: How many events make up the heptathlon?
questions.explanation: The heptathlon consists of 7 events contested over two days: 100m hurdles, high jump, shot put, 200m (day 1), long jump, javelin, 800m (day 2). It is primarily a women's event.

questions.question: What is the world record for the men's 100 meters, set by Usain Bolt?
questions.explanation: Usain Bolt set the world record for the 100 meters at 9.58 seconds at the 2009 World Championships in Berlin. This record remains unbroken.

questions.question: In the high jump, what technique do most modern jumpers use?
questions.explanation: The Fosbury Flop, pioneered by Dick Fosbury at the 1968 Olympics, involves jumping headfirst with the back facing the bar. It revolutionized the high jump and is now the dominant technique.

questions.question: What is a 'relay' in track and field?
options: A race where team members take turns running segments and passing a baton
Running back and forth on the track
questions.explanation: A relay race is a team event where four runners each run a portion of the total distance and pass a baton to the next runner. The most common relays are the 4x100m and 4x400m.

questions.question: What is the longest standard track race in the Olympics?
questions.explanation: The marathon at 42.195 km (26.2 miles) is the longest standard running race in the Olympics. The 50km race walk was removed from the Olympic program after 2020.

questions.question: What is the pole vault?
options: Jumping over a high bar using a flexible pole
questions.explanation: The pole vault is a track and field event where athletes use a long, flexible pole to launch themselves over a high bar. The current men's world record is over 6.20 meters (20+ feet).

questions.question: Which female sprinter is known as 'Flo-Jo' and set world records in the 100m and 200m?
questions.explanation: Florence Griffith Joyner, known as 'Flo-Jo,' set world records of 10.49 seconds (100m) and 21.34 seconds (200m) at the 1988 US Olympic Trials and Seoul Olympics. Both records still stand.

questions.question: How many hurdles do runners clear in the 110 meters hurdles?
questions.explanation: Runners clear 10 hurdles in the 110 meters hurdles (men) and 100 meters hurdles (women). The hurdles are 1.067 meters (3 feet 6 inches) high for men.

questions.question: What is the triple jump?
options: Three attempts at the long jump
A hop, step (skip), and jump sequence
questions.explanation: The triple jump consists of a hop, step (or skip), and jump performed in sequence from a running start. Athletes must land on the same foot they take off from for the hop phase.

questions.question: Which Jamaican sprinter won the 'triple-triple' â€” gold in 100m, 200m, and 4x100m at three consecutive Olympics?
questions.explanation: Usain Bolt won gold in the 100m, 200m, and 4x100m relay at the 2008, 2012, and 2016 Olympics (though his 2008 relay gold was later stripped due to a teammate's doping violation).

questions.question: What is a 'photo finish' in track and field?
options: When cameras capture the start of a race
When athletes pose for photos after a race
When fans take photos at the finish line
When the race result must be determined by examining a high-speed photograph
questions.explanation: A photo finish occurs when runners cross the finish line so close together that the naked eye cannot determine the winner, requiring a high-speed camera image to decide the result.

questions.question: What is the steeplechase in track and field?
options: A 3,000m race with barriers and water jumps
questions.explanation: The steeplechase is a 3,000-meter race in which athletes must clear 28 barriers and 7 water jumps. The name comes from horse racing over natural obstacles between church steeples.

questions.question: Which athlete won four gold medals at the 1936 Berlin Olympics in track and field?
questions.explanation: Jesse Owens won four gold medals at the 1936 Berlin Olympics in the 100m, 200m, long jump, and 4x100m relay, defying Nazi ideology about racial superiority.
